executive_summary: Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2021 currency. Due to growing demand for dialysis treatment, revenue for the Dialysis Equipment Manufacturing industry increased over the five years to 2021. The aging US population has increased the number of individuals with kidney diseases in recent years; according to the US Renal Data System (USRDS), the incidence of end-stage renal disease has increased at an annualized rate of 1.1% over the five years to 2018 (latest data available). Additionally, in 2020, downstream demand increased during the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic. Consequently, demand for dialysis treatment has grown, fueling growth for downstream kidney dialysis centers. IBISWorld expects industry revenue to increase at an annualized rate of 5.4% to $3.0 billion over the five years to 2021.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Demand for dialysis equipment is heavily driven by overall demand for dialysis treatment
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Typically, older individuals are more likely to develop chronic kidney diseases that require dialysis treatment. Over the five years to 2021, the median age of the US population is anticipated to rise at an annualized rate of 0.5%, leading to more incidences of kidney problems in the population.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Slow economic recovery made downstream operators hesitant to make capital outlays
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: However, while kidney dialysis centers experienced strong growth over the past five years, dialysis equipment manufacturers contended with stagnant demand during the period. Slow economic recovery across the United States made downstream operators more hesitant to make significant capital outlays, such as dialysis machine purchases.
In 2020, industry demand increased as a result of COVID-19 (coronavirus), and the long-term health effects associated with the virus.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Healthcare funding and reimbursement rates impacted demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Government funding for Medicare and Medicaid has strongly increased over the past five years due to both the aging US population and the PPACA. However, the PPACA has also threatened industry revenue, as the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) has imposed reimbursements cuts on many of the industry's largest downstream customers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Demand for dialysis treatment to increase as population ages
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Dialysis Equipment Manufacturing industry is forecast to grow steadily over the five years to 2026 as demand for dialysis treatment increases. The population is projected to continue aging, with the median age of the US population increasing at an annualized rate of 0.4% over the next five years.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Profit expected to remain low due to reimbursement constraints
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the next five years, industry profit is expected to remain low. Although health insurance coverage is forecast to increase during the outlook period, overall reimbursement for kidney dialysis treatment will be constrained. Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement cuts for dialysis treatment will be rolled out during a multiyear period, but will still ultimately affect care providers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Revenue growth from increasing insurance coverage and demand
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Largely due to the aging population, the incidence of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) is anticipated to increase during the same period, thus creating greater need for dialysis equipment. As a result, IBISWorld forecasts that industry revenue will grow at an annualized rate of 2.9% to total $3.5 billion over the five years to 2026.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: International trade to recover with rising overseas demand
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: International trade is anticipated to grow over the next five years due to strengthening demand for dialysis treatment across the world; in particular, demand from China is forecast to rise sharply. IBISWorld projects industry exports to increase at an annualized rate of 2.9% to $176.9 million over the five years to 2026.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Dialysis centers are the largest market for the Dialysis Equipment Manufacturing industry, estimated to generate 61.8% of total revenue in 2021. Dialysis centers are largely dominated by Fresenius Medical Care AG and Co. KGaA (Fresenius) and DaVita. Fresenius is the service branch of the largest dialysis equipment manufacturer, Fresenius. Most patients who have renal failure and need to be treated are done so at dialysis centers. Patients frequent centers three to four times a week and typically receive hemodialysis treatment.

Hospitals and other healthcare facilities are estimated to account for 33.1% of industry revenue in 2021. Some hospitals provide regular treatment services similar to dialysis centers; however, many of them purchase machines to treat individuals that have recently suffered kidney failure or need emergency dialysis treatment. In addition, this segment includes other care facilities such as senior-care or assisted living centers. Elderly people are at particularly high risk of kidney failure, with nearly 45.0% of people aged 65 and older experiencing some form of kidney failure, according to the Center for Disease Control.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Innovations and other intellectual property rights encourages new product development and consequently demand for products. Without sufficient protection for intellectual property, manufacturers do not have adequate incentive to invest the large sums needed in research and development to develop new products. As demand is driven by new product introductions, intellectual property protection is an important factor supporting demand for dialysis equipment.

Another important demand factor is the level of capital expenditure (both public and private) on equipment in the healthcare sector. Spending by hospitals and other markets is strongly affected by capital expenditure on health services. The age of capital equipment will determine demand for products. This factor has particularly weighed on industry performance over the past five years as the poor economic climate made hospitals and clinics hesitant to make long-term purchases and investments, such as dialysis machines.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region maintains 33.0% of total industry establishments, lower than its 25.7% share of the national population. A presence in this region enables manufacturers access to less expensive labor compared with other regions of the United States, such as the Mid-Atlantic. In addition, many states in the Southeast are considered to be a part of the "diabetes belt"

The Mid-Atlantic region is one of the most populated regions in terms of establishments with 13.1%, close to its 15.1% share of the total population. The Mid-Atlantic is a highly populated region with a vast number of colleges and universities, so this region often creates new products for the industry to sell. As a leader in innovation, this region attracts more manufacturers.
The Great Lakes region holds 15.7% of industry establishments, while holding 14.4% of the population.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The FDA governs laws and regulations relating to development, testing, manufacturing, labeling, marketing and distribution of medical devices.
Manufacturers must get FDA premarket notification 510(k) or premarket approval (PMA) to market new medical devices.
Good manufacturing practices require quality systems for design, manufacture, packaging, labeling, storage, installation and servicing.
Manufacturers must report deaths, injuries, malfunctions and track certain high-risk devices for potential recalls.
Imports are subject to same regulations as domestic goods. Unapproved devices can only be imported for export purposes.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Medical devices like dialysis machines are subject to regulations established by acts like the Federal Food Drug and Cosmetic Act, FDA Modernization Acts, and Medical Device User Fee Acts.
The industry's two largest operators account for 69.3% of total revenue, making it difficult for new entrants to capture significant market share.
There are very few operators in the industry who know their competitors well and compete aggressively on innovation, quality and performance.
There is a fast rate of technological change in the industry, requiring significant investment in R&D for new product development.
Most products are manufactured under patent, so new entrants must have original designs and functionality.

basis_points.basis_description: Operators largely compete on innovation, as technological developments can provide competitive advantage.
Quality and performance are important competitive factors since dialysis equipment affects patient health.
Price is a significant factor as healthcare providers push for price concessions, but large operators can ease price competition by offering services.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Fresenius Medical Care and Baxter International account for a combined 69.3% of industry revenue.
No other company generates more than 5% of industry revenue.

top_companies.company_name: Fresenius Medical Care AG & Co. KGaA

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, is expected to account for 5.2% of revenue for the Dialysis Equipment Manufacturing industry in 2021. Profit has contracted over the five years to 2021 due largely to price reductions by the industry's largest companies.

Wages are a major cost for industry operators. Skilled workers are needed to design and manufacture dialysis machines, since medical devices typically incorporate a high level of technology. As a result, technicians, designers and engineers can command high wages.

Dialysis equipment manufacturers need to purchase a variety of material, from circuit boards, wiring and computing equipment to filters and basic metal parts. Over the past five years, purchase costs have remained relatively steady.
Depreciation is expected to account for 1.5% of revenue in 2021. Over the past five years, depreciation costs have remained steady as industry companies expanded automated manufacturing operations.
Marketing accounts for a minimal share of industry revenue, since most industry companies have distribution deals with downstream dialysis centers.
Rent is estimated to make up 1.0% of revenue in 2021. Industry operators own the majority of manufacturing facilities, since facility ownership is typically more cost effective over a long timeframe.

Utility expenses slightly decreased due to low electricity and natural gas prices over the past five years. IBISWorld anticipates utilities to account for 0.5% of industry revenue, remaining relatively unchanged from 2016.
Administration, insurance, research and development (R&D) and other miscellaneous expenses account for the remaining 29.3% of industry revenue.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Wages in the industry represent a significant cost, totaling 23.9% of revenue, since skilled workers are needed in the design and manufacture of dialysis machines.

Industry products are still relatively new, with most products having only been on the market for the past 50 years. As a result, operators spend on research and development (i.e., labor) to design smaller, more efficient machines to gain market share.
Operators have, to some extent, invested in automation in recent years, increasing depreciation's share of revenue for the average industry operator.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Operators experienced some fluctuations stemming from downstream reimbursement cuts and subsequent price adjustments.
Revenue increased overall during the current period due to rising demand for dialysis treatment as the population aged.
Industry operators experienced increased demand for products due to COVID-19 (coronavirus), with revenue increasing 8.0% in 2020.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Sales are driven by the introduction of new products to the market, and product development is driven by technological advances.
Operators must gain access to the latest technology through their research and development efforts.
Operators are working toward the development of smaller products to simplify use and continue the development of the consumer market.
Operators are working on developing equipment that uses sorbent technology for the recycling of tap water during the dialysis process.

FAQs.question: How does an increase in certain age groups affect your company's performance?
FAQs.answer: Demand for dialysis treatment is highest from the elderly who have the highest risk of kidney failure

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in new technology to improve internal processes?
FAQs.answer: New record keeping software can make manufacturing processes more efficient

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Automation and robotics have made manufacturing more efficient and reduced dependence on labor

FAQs.question: Have any new mandates, as a result of healthcare reform, expanded your client base?
FAQs.answer: The expansion of private insurance has led to greater demand for dialysis treatment, and therefore equipment

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Dialysis equipment manufacturers are held to high standards, because their products are crucial for patient survival

FAQs.question: What ongoing financing challenges does your company face?
FAQs.answer: Lower reimbursement rates have resulted in decreased profit margins for manufacturers
